The Rain Bird 
 Joane Bloch (retold folktale) 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 In a country caled Gabon, a litle vilage
 stod at the very edge of a forest. In the
 
 heart of this forest, in the highest
 branches of an enormous tre, lived a
 very special bird − the bird that made
 
 rain. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 For as far back as the vilagers could 
 remember, they had taken the time to 
 
 kep this bird hapy. They saved scraps 
 of bread, pieces of fruit and fresh 
 coconut milk, and every wek or two a 
 
 group of vilagers tok these delicacies 
 into the forest. When they had laid them 
 
 at the base of the tre, one of them 
 played a simple tune on the thumb piano. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 After a while, the bird flew down to the
 ground to eat and drink. When she had
 finished, she began to sing the most
 
 beautiful song. 
 
 At the same time, she raised her dark,
 
 shiny blue wings, and within minutes, the
 rain began to fal. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 This went on for many years. Because 
 
 the rain fel regularly, the crops grew 
 abundantly and there was plenty of fod 
 in the vilage. 
 
 
 But gradualy things began to change. 
 Somehow, the vilagers were always busy 
 
 and they began to neglect the rain bird. 
 "It wil rain anyway," they said. "It’s time to 
 
 stop spoiling that sily old bird!" 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 But the people were wrong. When they
 
 stoped loking after the bird, the rain
 stoped faling. 
 
 
 The crops began to dry up and die, and
 the animals grew thin and weak. Stil,
 
 nobody in the vilage went into the forest
 to fed the bird that brought the rain.
 
 Now they were al to busy trying to find
 money to buy fod in the neighbouring
 town. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One scorching day, a young girl caled Keti decided to go into the forest
 
 after schol. "At least it wil be col in there," she thought to herself. She
 walked and walked, and after some time, she came to the tal tre in which
 the rain bird lived. Keti stared up at the tre. 
 
 
 Sudenly, she remembered how her grany had taken her into the forest to
 fed the bird when she was stil a tiny child. Keti opened her schol bag and
 
 puled out a piece of bread left over from her lunch. Carefuly she laid the
 bread at the base of the tre. Then, because she had no thumb piano with
 
 her, she sang an old song that she had known al her life. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 With a loud whoshing sound, a beautiful
 
 blue bird swoped out of the branches
 above Keti’s head and began to eat the
 
 bread. When the bird had finished, she
 opened her mouth and sang a few pure,
 high notes. 
 
 Then she raised her shiny wings and al
 of a suden Keti heard the rumble of
 
 thunder. By the time she reached her
 home, giant rain drops were pelting
 down, coling the baking red earth.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Keti was very hapy, until she told her parents what had hapened. "Don’t
 
 be sily!" scolded her mother. "Nobody believes that bird has anything to do
 with the rain anymore!" 
 
 "Your mother is right," said Keti’s father. "The drought has ben broken now
 and we wil be fine. Don’t go wasting god bread feding that gredy old bird
 again!" 
 
 
 Though Keti didn’t argue with her parents, she felt sure they were wrong. "If
 
 only Grany were stil alive," she said to herself, "she would have believed
 me!" But Keti’s grany had died a few years earlier. The only thing Keti had
 left, was her grany’s old thumb piano. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Two weks pased and there was no
 more rain. The crops began to shrivel up
 
 again and the hungry animals’ ribs began
 to stick out even more. The sun beat
 down mercilesly from a glaring blue sky.
 
 
 "I don’t care what they say!" thought
 
 Keti. "We ned rain. I’m going to fed the
 bird again tomorow!" 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So, early the next morning, after taking a 
 
 slice of bread and a handful of red 
 beries from the kitchen, Keti sliped out 
 
 of the house. She began to make her way 
 to the centre of the forest. 
 
 
 What she didn’t realise, was that her 
 father was also awake. When he saw 
 
 what his daughter was doing, he realised 
 that she was going to fed the rain bird 
 again. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 "I’l teach that disobedient child a leson!" he said to himself angrily. He
 
 snatched his bow and arows and silently folowed Keti into the forest.
 
 
 Just as the bird flew down to eat the fod that Keti had set out for it, her
 father raised his bow and released his deadly arow. The arow flew straight
 into the bird’s heart. The bird let out a piercing shriek. 
 
 
 Terified, Keti spun around − just in time to se her father fal down, stone
 
 dead. Keti screamed and turned around − just in time to se the arow fal
 harmlesly from the bird’s glosy body. Then the bird, unharmed, swoped
 up into the highest branch of the tre. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Keti raced out of the forest to a scene of
 
 uter devastation. Every animal and every
 person she saw lay dead on the ground.
 With a pounding heart, she ran al the
 
 way back to her home. 
 
 She quickly found her grany’s old thumb
 
 piano. "This is my only hope!" she
 thought. "The rain bird is angry. I have to
 
 make her hapy again! I HAVE to!"
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 15  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Half an hour later, Keti was back at the 
 base of the big tre. Her body was 
 
 drenched with sweat and she was 
 gasping for breath. A few paces away 
 
 from her lay the lifeles body of her 
 father. 
 
 
 Keti loked away quickly, and with 
 trembling hands, began to play the 
 
 thumb piano. 
 
 She played and played, until her fingers 
 
 hurt. 
 
 
 
 
 
 16  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Finaly, what she wanted most in the
 
 world hapened. Down swoped the bird
 as if nothing had hapened. The bird ate
 some of the beries stil lying on the
 
 ground and sang a few notes. Then, as
 Keti played on, the bird raised her wings.
 
 Keti heard a rustle behind her.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 17  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 It was her father who had woken up. 
 
 "I’m sory!" he said again and again to the 
 big, blue bird. 
 Then he held out his hand to his 
 
 daughter and they walked slowly back to 
 the vilage. In the vilage al the people 
 
 and animals were alive again. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 18  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 That night the vilagers held a meting.
 They al agred that they had learned a
 
 valuable leson. And from that day
 onwards, not one wek pased without a
 special trip to the forest to fed the bird
 
 that brought the rain. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 19
